items.content_html:
This deletes all the docs under https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Plugins and redirects them to a new glossary entry.

Plugins are an outdated technology no longer supported by any modern browsers. These docs did include a migration guide that looked as if it might have been helpful: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Plugins/Flash_to_HTML5 but we're surely past that point now that Flash is no longer supported in any modern browsers, and the deprecation process lasted several years.
items.title: Remove plugins docs: redirect to new glossary page

items.content_html:
Fixes #10005

The example is supposed to show how you can use curl to follow redirects to a link, and how you can use other tools like grep and awk to filter and modify the results.

It is broken because the MDN URL used for the example has been "fixed" so it is no longer a redirect. Damn that flaw fixer :-).
The original URL used in the git blame is https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/fetch.
So I have put that back in.

It redirects to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch in just one hop. The docs seemed to think that there would be three hops but that has perhaps been tidied in the redirects.txt. In any case, the fix I have made just refers to the one hop now.
The "link to test" is only ever displayed in code style, so should not get "fixed" again.

It is enough to see what is going on.
items.title: Command line tools - fix redirect

items.content_html:
Fixes #9861

This fixes the first part of the example so that people can see load the plugin and see it working. For that section it replaces the youtube with a screenshot.

Note,

This does not completely fix the page - there are still non-working examples and youtube videos. The second part redirects all links to https://mdn.mozillademos.org/* to a tumbler image. The problem is that MDN no longer uses that for our images and the tumbler image would fail CSP check. We might update the example to use something that will work - use developer.moz for the images and redirect to another image we know will work.

I have chosen not to do this. I understand these are getting a more thorough review at some point. Only did this to add the information already gathered.

var pattern = "https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/*";

function redirect(requestDetails) {
  console.log("Redirecting: " + requestDetails.url);
  return {
    redirectUrl: "https://developer.mozilla.org/favicon-48x48-flawless.png"
  };
}

browser.webRequest.onBeforeRequest.addListener(
  redirect,
  {urls:[pattern], types:["image"]},
  ["blocking"]
);
items.title: WebExt - intercept HTTP request easy fix to content messages

items.content_html:
Fixes #10524

This is not precisely a "fix" but is a slight improvement to Array.prototype.reduce() that fell out of the discussion (i.e. that issue is not actually a bug, but did make us think we could improve this).

What this does:

  • In introduction provides overview of what happens in the first iteration.
  • Splits the with/without initial value examples into separate headings and just uses arrow functions. Also uses different array values so that the things that relevant points are easier to see in the tables (i.e. the index iteration and the movement of the previousValue.

A really thorough fix might be to replace the spec inclusion in the description with hand written text. I could do that, and I think it would be good, but there are things I consider higher value at this point.
items.title: array.reduce() improvements

items.content_html:
Summary

The order of stacking context hierarchy was changed to ascending order of z-index.

Before Changes:

  • root stacking context
    • DIV 2 (z-index 2)
    • DIV 3 (z-index 1)
      • DIV 4 (z-index 10)

After Changes:

  • root stacking context
    • DIV 3 (z-index 1)
      • DIV 4 (z-index 10)
    • DIV 2 (z-index 2)

Supporting details

Related Link: The_stacking_context

Related issues

Fixes #10543

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Content: Corrections in stacking context hierarchy

items.content_html:
Fixes #10521

This banged on about how there were 6 regular expression flags, but there are now 7. The fix adds the missing flag d.

Also adds links to the information on what the flags do and clarifies (from spec) that using the same valid flag multiple times can also cause this error. Also links to the table where we define the flags (but continues to reproduce it).

As an aside

@teoli2003 Can you explain what this d flag is actually used for?
The documentation of hasIndices confuses me. It seems to indicate that instead of the result being an array of matches, you get an array indicating the start and end points of the match? If so, what's the point?

Further, it seems to indicate that if you do use d you can then access something called indecies but that isn't documented. Or am I missing something very obvious?
items.title: invalid re flag message - add d flag

items.content_html:
Part of #10337 .

This PR updates https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Useful_string_methods.

  • teach includes() as a way of finding whether a string contains a substring, rather than indexOf()
  • separate "finding out whether a string contains a substring" and "extracting a substring"
  • add startsWith() and endsWith()
  • use const and for...of where possible
  • bump sections up to H2 so they appear in the ToC
items.title: Updates to JS Learning Area String: useful methods page

items.content_html:
Part of #10337.

This PR makes some updates to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Arrays .

Functionally the main things I wanted to do here were:

  • teach for...of for iterating through an array, rather than for(;;)
  • introduce map() and filter()

But I also added a bit on indexOf() (which IMO is a really basic thing to know) and splice() (since it talks a lot about removing items from the start or end, and it seems natural to want to know how to remove items from the middle).

I also made some structural updates:

  • reordering sections: at the moment some features were under "what is an array?" and others under "useful array methods" for no apparent reason
  • putting all sections in H2 headings (I would probably have put them under H3 headings under a single "Array features" or something, but our glorious ToC only shows H2 headings).

I've also tried to make examples self-contained, so they can be pasted into a console on their own rather than depending on previous examples having been pasted in. This approach has the drawbacks that the console will complain about variables being redeclared, but on balance I think it is easier to work with.

I haven't replaced let with const in existing code - I want to do these in their own task.

BTW IMO the "active learning" tooling is not very good either from a writer or a reader point of view. No syntax highlighting, no clear styling of output, no diagnostics when you make a mistake, editing in a little iframe. I mean they work and it's good that we have them, but should really consider an upgrade while we are looking at example systems.

I haven't yet added a new exercise to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/First_steps/Test_your_skills:_Arrays, but will do (in a separate PR) after mdn/learning-area#418 is merged.
items.title: Updates to JS Learning Area Arrays page

items.content_html:
Summary

Fixes the precedence table for yield and ??.

Motivation

There are at least two inaccuracies in the JavaScript operator-precedence table.

  • yield/yield * have equal precedence with = and the other assignment operators (AssignmentExpression). This is why x = yield 1 is valid in a generator, while x + yield 1 is invalid.
  • || and ?? have equal precedence (ShortCircuitExpression). Their grammar is such that they are mutually exclusive—they cannot be used together without parentheses—but they nevertheless have equal precedence.

Related issues

Fixes #5365.

Metadata

This PR…

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Fix precedence table for `yield` and `??`
